node.text:
Summary of how dopamine and compounds that increase dopamine increase our level of focus. I also review research supported behavioral protocols for increasing focus. 
-
Many people struggle to focus not just those with ADHD. Understanding how your dopamine brain circuits work can help. 
-
For instance, caffeine increases alertness but also the density of dopamine receptors. There are also compounds that tap into the acetylcholine system that augment dopamine for sake of focus. I discuss those here and in more depth on the podcast. 
-
Whether by pharmacology or by behavioral practices or both, everyone can increase their capacity to focus. People with ADHD obviously should work with a MD clinician to figure out the best approach. 
-
You can find the link to the podcast in my profile bio. It’s available there in all formats, time stamped so you can jump to the specific topic of interest, and captioned. 
-
Please put your questions about ADHD and focus and dopamine in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #adhd #focus #dopamine #nootropics #acetylcholine #neuroplasticity #concentration #choline #alert #caffeine

node.text:
The use of cold exposure to increase fat loss and feelings of mental well-being and clarity is not a new phenomenon. There is however some recent science that points to the correct way to stimulate metabolism and fat loss and increase dopamine for sake of mental well being by using cold exposure. Here I review those findings and offer some possible protocols.
-
Be smart about cold exposure: if you get into a body of water that is extremely cold your heart can stop. Everyone has different thresholds for this. 
-
Also understand that when you become cold adapted, you no longer shiver and won’t stimulate as much metabolic increase or potential fat loss. 
-
Please put any questions you have in the comment section below this post. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #metabolism #fatloss #succinate #dopamine #prague #shiver #adrenaline #biochemistry

node.text:
All of us, including those with ADHD can experience immediate and extremely sharp focus for topics and events we are interested in and curious about. 
-
How does that work? Why is it that focusing is reflexive when we are interested in something? 
-
The answer resides in dopamine and the way that dopamine impacts our visual and auditory perceptions, and indeed, our perceptions in general. 
-
Dopamine is a neuromodulator and it can switch on the activation of specific neural circuits related to focus and concentration and memory. That is why many of the pharmacologic treatments for ADHD revolve around increasing dopamine levels in one way or another. 
-
For people without ADHD, chronically elevating dopamine may not be the best choice. In this weeks Huberman Lab Podcast I describe various alternatives that tap into the dopamine system but also other neuromodulator systems that can have a powerful impact on focus such as novel nootropics and new generation cholinergic agents.
-
I also review behavioral protocols for increasing focus in ADHD and for people simply trying to increase their level of concentration.
-
You can find the link to the podcast in my profile bio. It’s available there in all formats.
-
Please put your questions about ADHD and focus and dopamine in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #adhd #focus #dopamine #nootropics #acetylcholine #neuroplasticity #concentration #noopept #blinks

node.text:
The hormones that regulate reproduction and other types of adaptive behaviors are some of the most hardwired aspects of our biology. Meaning, the neural and endocrine circuits that control them are very robust and evolved to respond to particular cues such as the presence of mates, food, etc. 
-
Here I describe a classic study in which levels of lutenizing hormone and testosterone- hormones that are critical for mating and reproduction etc. in both males and females, can be conditioned to be released at much higher levels (nearly double!) according to prior experience. 
-
The same is true for insulin, a hormone that’s involved in regulating blood sugar. Insulin is released when we anticipate food we enjoy. The presence of the food is not required.
-
This speaks to the power of thoughts in regulating what would otherwise be hardwired physiological processes. 
-
Keep in mind that levels of hormones won’t increase in response to a cue unless the first exposure to that cue was paired with something that actually stimulates that hormone directly. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always, thank you for your interest in science!
_
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from the most recent Huberman Lab Podcast about Healthy Eating and Eating Disorders.
-
Research into anorexia nervosa points to the fact that the reward system has been rewired to create a heightened level of vigilance for the caloric and fat content of foods, and an almost reflexive habit-like behavior of rewarding food avoidance.
-
There are many different treatments for anorexia but one often successful approach is to identify the shift in internal state (“interoception”) that precedes the habit of hyper-acuity for food content. In fact one of the tests for anorexia includes assessing what is called “central coherence” or the ability to see the whole picture and not just the details.
-
While this segment is specifically about anorexia and its treatment the principles and neural circuitry involved relate to breaking habits of all kinds, food related or otherwise. 
-
For additional details see the full episode by following the link in my profile bio. It’s available in video and audio formats, is time stamped and captioned.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Future guest suggestions also welcome. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-

node.text:
When the sun is low in the sky the contrast between yellow and blue wavelengths is greatest and that is what allows the specific neurons in your retina/eye to set your circadian clock. 
-
I recommend viewing sunlight when the sun is at low solar angle in the morning and again in the evening as many days as possible. If you miss a day that’s not such a huge deal but try not to miss two days in a row.
-
This will keep circadian timing mechanisms in your brain and body tuned up appropriately. That means better sleep, proper timing of cortisol release and neuromodulators like dopamine and serotonin as well. This equates to better mood and learning. These are all statements backed by quality peer reviewed research in mice and humans. 
-
How long to view it? That depends on how bright it is and whether or not there’s any cloud cover. If there’s cloud cover and you can’t see the blue yellow contrast don’t worry it’s still coming through those clouds. If it’s a very bright cloudless day then 2-10 minutes is usually sufficient. On a cloudy day 30 minutes is better. And if you live someplace where it is dark and dreary then consider using an artificial light that is quite bright to mimic sunlight. 
I mentioned an inexpensive option on the Tim Ferris Podcast @timferriss a few months back. (Easy to find those show notes and links by searching our names online.)
-
Contacts and eyeglasses won’t disrupt this process -in fact they focus light to the eye. But looking through a window does not work well for this purpose; It takes much longer to set the circadian clock. 50 times longer in fact.
-
Never look at any light so bright that it’s painful to look at. You don’t want to damage your retina. Wear sunglasses or do not depending on how sensitive your eyes are. That varies. 
-
Put questions you have in the comment section and thank you for your interest in science! 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
In this excerpt from the most recent episode of The Huberman Lab Podcast my colleague Dr. Robert Sapolsky (Professor of Biology & Neurosurgery @stanford & @stanford.med) shares his views on free will and his general stance that humans lack free will. 
-
As the conversation continues he brings forward the argument that despite this, he believes it is possible for humans to make better choices for the sake of themselves, their communities, and the trajectory of all humans. 
-
Dr. Sapolsky is working on a new book called “Determined” that further explores this topic at the biological, psychological and societal level. 
-
To hear our full conversation follow the link in my profile bio; it is available in audio and video format with subtitles and time stamps. New episodes out every Monday. 
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #freewill #genetics #biology #determined #hardwired #neuroplasticity #choice #descartes

node.text:
A new study just published in @cellpress shows that sunlight exposure to the skin (and eyes) of mice or humans increases mating behavior, & the perception of others’ smell as more attractive, and to aggression. 
-
It appears the skin is acting as a hormone-promoting organ to exert these effects. p53 in keratinocyte skin cells can activate the pituitary gland and hypothalamus if the skin is exposed to ample sunlight (UV-B light in particular…). That in turn, causes increases in LH/FSH that trigger testosterone, estradiol and progesterone.
-
The duration of sunlight exposure was four hours. It only took two days to see these effects. 
-
I also discuss how attractiveness of female odor is modulated by the menstrual cycle and how that effect is eliminated by oral contraceptives which makes sense if it’s tied to ovulation. 
-
Note: the UV light exposure was to the upper body and face and no, your screens can’t recreate that and infrared sauna won’t either. (Infrared is the opposite end of the wavelength spectrum).
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford @stanford.med @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @samerhattar 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #sun #light #sunlight #testosterone #estrogren #progesterone #hormones #aggression #p53 #hypothalamus #skin #UVB #endocrine #romance

node.text:
Hormones such as Testosterone and Estrogen have a profound effect on the brain and body beginning long before birth. 
-
Testosterone exposure from the pregnant mother and from the fetus itself drives a difference in the D2:D4 (index finger to ring finger) length ratio, on the right hand. 
-
In the right hand of females, these two fingers tend to be more similar in length whereas in males the D2 tends to be shorter that D4 (subtly, but the difference exists). 
(Williams et al., Nature 2000). 
-
Note: This result has been replicated many times over in different populations. You also see interesting data in terms of romantic partner preference in adulthood related to D2:D4 ratios. I describe those findings in the HLPodcast episode on Hormones and Development (link in bio).
-
NOTE: the D2:D4 have to be measured properly with calipers. Eyeballing it doesn’t work!
-
Nonetheless this speaks to the important “organizing” role that hormones have on the developing brain and body and the later so-called “activating” effects of hormones later in life. 
-
Here I discuss these results with Dr. Robert Sapolsky on the Huberman Lab Podcast (link to full discussion in profile bio). 
-
Put your questions in the comment section below this post and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @nature_the_journal 
-

node.text:
Dopamine and Testosterone collaborate to create our motivated states, our desire to push forward toward goals and our willingness to meet challenges of all kinds. 
-
The key is ALL kinds. Testosterone and Dopamine don’t create goals or behaviors they create an action state in the body that makes all people, men and women, more willing to engage in effort to reach for whatever it is that we personally find desirable. 
-
Here I discuss that process with Dr. Robert Sapolsky
on The Huberman Lab Podcast.
-
Find the full episode (in all formats with time stamps and captions) by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with guest Dr Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D.  from @stanford.med @stanford 
-
There are so many misconceptions about testosterone and what it does to human thinking and behavior. 
-
Here we discuss the science of testosterone on the brain and how testosterone serves to amplify pre-existing tendencies and behaviors, effort and competition *even if that competition involves no aggression at all.*
-
Find the full episode in all formats with time stamps and captions by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast episode out now on Depression and how to treat it. 
-
One of the most striking features of major depression is how it changes the narrative of the person suffering, even to the point where they are disconnected from reality in a way that makes them genuinely underestimate their performance in life.
-
In the full episode (link in bio) I caution against self diagnosing depression. However it is important to take signs such as anti-self confabulation and the other symptoms seriously; I explain what those are, how to get an accurate diagnosis and some of the different forms of treatment. 
-
I also discuss some of the science supportive tools for keeping depression at bay and offer protocols.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @bbrfoundation 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociência #depression #dementia
#serotonin #dopamine #confabulation #mentalhealth #physicalhealth

node.text:
Summary of how dopamine and compounds that increase dopamine increase our level of focus. I also review research supported behavioral protocols for increasing focus. 
-
Many people struggle to focus not just those with ADHD. Understanding how your dopamine brain circuits work can help. 
-
For instance, caffeine increases alertness but also the density of dopamine receptors. There are also compounds that tap into the acetylcholine system that augment dopamine for sake of focus. I discuss those here and in more depth on the podcast. 
-
Whether by pharmacology or by behavioral practices or both, everyone can increase their capacity to focus. People with ADHD obviously should work with a MD clinician to figure out the best approach. 
-
You can find the link to the podcast in my profile bio. It’s available there in all formats, time stamped so you can jump to the specific topic of interest, and captioned. 
-

node.text:
The use of cold exposure to increase fat loss and feelings of mental well-being and clarity is not a new phenomenon. There is however some recent science that points to the correct way to stimulate metabolism and fat loss and increase dopamine for sake of mental well being by using cold exposure. Here I review those findings and offer some possible protocols.
-
Be smart about cold exposure: if you get into a body of water that is extremely cold your heart can stop. Everyone has different thresholds for this. 
-
Also understand that when you become cold adapted, you no longer shiver and won’t stimulate as much metabolic increase or potential fat loss. 
-
Please put any questions you have in the comment section below this post. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #metabolism #fatloss #succinate #dopamine #prague #shiver #adrenaline #biochemistry

node.text:
All of us, including those with ADHD can experience immediate and extremely sharp focus for topics and events we are interested in and curious about. 
-
How does that work? Why is it that focusing is reflexive when we are interested in something? 
-
The answer resides in dopamine and the way that dopamine impacts our visual and auditory perceptions, and indeed, our perceptions in general. 
-
Dopamine is a neuromodulator and it can switch on the activation of specific neural circuits related to focus and concentration and memory. That is why many of the pharmacologic treatments for ADHD revolve around increasing dopamine levels in one way or another. 
-
For people without ADHD, chronically elevating dopamine may not be the best choice. In this weeks Huberman Lab Podcast I describe various alternatives that tap into the dopamine system but also other neuromodulator systems that can have a powerful impact on focus such as novel nootropics and new generation cholinergic agents.
-
I also review behavioral protocols for increasing focus in ADHD and for people simply trying to increase their level of concentration.
-
You can find the link to the podcast in my profile bio. It’s available there in all formats.
-
Please put your questions about ADHD and focus and dopamine in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #adhd #focus #dopamine #nootropics #acetylcholine #neuroplasticity #concentration #noopept #blinks

node.text:
NEW PODCAST: ADHD & IMPROVING FOCUS IN ALL PEOPLE•
-
This episode covers neural circuits, behavioral treatments, pharmacologic treatments, and new emerging tools for attention deficit hyper activity disorder (ADHD). Many of these tools are also applicable for people who do not have ADHD but are interested in improving their focus.
-
I also review the data on diet in particular elimination diets for ADHD, DHAs and allergies and ADHD. I review compounds that can improve concentration and focus that tap into different neurotransmitter systems, not just dopamine. 
-
As always, basic science and science supported tools are covered. You can find the link to the episode in my profile bio or by simply going to hubermanlab.com
-
The episode is time stamped and captioned (note that captions take 24hrs). You’ll find in YouTube Apple and Spotify formats. 
-
Please put your questions about ADHD and focus and tools for those in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
HUBERMAN LAB NEWSLETTER: PROTOCOLS, SCIENCE & REFERENCES• 
-
The first Huberman Lab “Neural Network” newsletter comes out a week from Sunday (9/19/21). It will include protocols and information not covered on Instagram or the podcast. It is of course zero-cost and will have links to additional resources that may be of use for things like sleep, learning, stress mitigation, nutrition, training, mental training, and more. 
-
If there are specific things you would like to hear more about in the newsletter, please put that in the comments section below this post. 
-
The sign up is easy: you just enter your email, click submit and then you will get a “verify” email sent to you. Verify it, and you’re set to receive our newsletter. Easy to unsubscribe as well. Our privacy policy is to not share your information at all, and if you want additional information on privacy it’s all found at hubermanlab.com
-
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford 
-
#neuroscience #science #tools #health #mentalhealth #humanperformance #2021

node.text:
The hormones that regulate reproduction and other types of adaptive behaviors are some of the most hardwired aspects of our biology. Meaning, the neural and endocrine circuits that control them are very robust and evolved to respond to particular cues such as the presence of mates, food, etc. 
-
Here I describe a classic study in which levels of lutenizing hormone and testosterone- hormones that are critical for mating and reproduction etc. in both males and females, can be conditioned to be released at much higher levels (nearly double!) according to prior experience. 
-
The same is true for insulin, a hormone that’s involved in regulating blood sugar. Insulin is released when we anticipate food we enjoy. The presence of the food is not required.
-
This speaks to the power of thoughts in regulating what would otherwise be hardwired physiological processes. 
-
Keep in mind that levels of hormones won’t increase in response to a cue unless the first exposure to that cue was paired with something that actually stimulates that hormone directly. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always, thank you for your interest in science!
_
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurosciencia #hormones #learning #pavlovian #insulin #estradiol #lutenizinghormone #testosterone 
#smellsgood #mmm #appetite

node.text:
SLEEPING BETTER: IT’S ALL BUT A DREAM.
-
Repost of remix by @juanjo_sound
“Lullaby” conversation of @drmattwalker as a guest on The Huberman Lab Podcast.
-
For the full episode (sans music) including how to get better at sleeping, power of short naps, and the effects of alcohol, caffeine, exercise and many other behaviors and compounds on sleep, see the link in my profile bio. 
-
Matt: usually when they say that when we speak “it cures insomnia” it’s an insult but in your case it’s a compliment… I on the other hand, have no excuse. 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @ucberkeleyofficial @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #sleep #dreamy #REM #SWS #eyes #hallucinations #insomniac

node.text:
Excerpt from the most recent Huberman Lab Podcast about Healthy Eating and Eating Disorders.
-
Research into anorexia nervosa points to the fact that the reward system has been rewired to create a heightened level of vigilance for the caloric and fat content of foods, and an almost reflexive habit-like behavior of rewarding food avoidance.
-
There are many different treatments for anorexia but one often successful approach is to identify the shift in internal state (“interoception”) that precedes the habit of hyper-acuity for food content. In fact one of the tests for anorexia includes assessing what is called “central coherence” or the ability to see the whole picture and not just the details.
-
While this segment is specifically about anorexia and its treatment the principles and neural circuitry involved relate to breaking habits of all kinds, food related or otherwise. 
-
For additional details see the full episode by following the link in my profile bio. It’s available in video and audio formats, is time stamped and captioned.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Future guest suggestions also welcome. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-

node.text:
When the sun is low in the sky the contrast between yellow and blue wavelengths is greatest and that is what allows the specific neurons in your retina/eye to set your circadian clock. 
-
I recommend viewing sunlight when the sun is at low solar angle in the morning and again in the evening as many days as possible. If you miss a day that’s not such a huge deal but try not to miss two days in a row.
-
This will keep circadian timing mechanisms in your brain and body tuned up appropriately. That means better sleep, proper timing of cortisol release and neuromodulators like dopamine and serotonin as well. This equates to better mood and learning. These are all statements backed by quality peer reviewed research in mice and humans. 
-
How long to view it? That depends on how bright it is and whether or not there’s any cloud cover. If there’s cloud cover and you can’t see the blue yellow contrast don’t worry it’s still coming through those clouds. If it’s a very bright cloudless day then 2-10 minutes is usually sufficient. On a cloudy day 30 minutes is better. And if you live someplace where it is dark and dreary then consider using an artificial light that is quite bright to mimic sunlight. 
I mentioned an inexpensive option on the Tim Ferris Podcast @timferriss a few months back. (Easy to find those show notes and links by searching our names online.)
-
Contacts and eyeglasses won’t disrupt this process -in fact they focus light to the eye. But looking through a window does not work well for this purpose; It takes much longer to set the circadian clock. 50 times longer in fact.
-
Never look at any light so bright that it’s painful to look at. You don’t want to damage your retina. Wear sunglasses or do not depending on how sensitive your eyes are. That varies. 
-
Put questions you have in the comment section and thank you for your interest in science! 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #sun #sunset #sunrise #health #sleep #mood #dopamine #obeybiology #toolsforhealth #scn

node.text:
WHAT IS HEATHY EATING? WHAT IS AN EATING DISORDER? 
-
New episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast out now all about the science of hunger, satiety, why we eat and why we stop eating. I discuss new data on timing of protein intake, and why for those intermittent fasting, it may be better to shift your meals to early in the day.
-
Then I discuss clinical eating disorders - anorexia, bulimia and binge eating disorder, including the common myth that media images are making anorexia more prevalent. 
-
I discuss treatments: habit-reshaping, family-based models, brain mechanisms and role of thyroid hormones and prescription treatments and exploratory trials for novel compounds to rewire the brain of people suffering from eating disorders. 
-
I also discuss how the brain of anorexics evaluates food differently at the mechanistic level, and brain areas being targeted for treatment of binge eating. 
-
I also cover “cheat days”: what these do to the brain and how body dysmorphia occurs and can be rewired. 
-
You can find the episode by following the link in my profile bio. It is there in all formats with captions. 
-
Meanwhile, please put your questions and guest suggestions  in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science! 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-

node.text:
LEX FRIDMAN PODCAST with 
DR VINCENT RACANIELLO:
-
This is an extremely important podcast episode that I believe everyone should see/listen to. 
-
They cover the topic of viruses: What they are, how they work, the knowns and the unknowns (!), mRNA technology and of course they explore all the topics relevant to what’s going on today. 
-
It’s an extremely balanced and thoughtful conversation start-to- finish and unlike any other conversation out there on this topic. I found it to be particularly refreshing because the conversation wasn’t trying to drive a particular choice or outcome but rather just educate. 
-
Note: A number of people of asked me to cover this topic on the Huberman Lab Podcast but frankly this podcast accomplishes anything I would’ve been capable of doing much better, plus far more. Lex and Vincent are simply that good! 
-
I learned so much and I know that you will too!
-
You can find the podcast on Apple, Spotify or YouTube or by going to: 

lexfridman.com/podcast/
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @profvrr @lexfridman @columbiamed 
-
